media.caption: Aerial View of IUPUI
media.credit: VISION & MISSION

text.headline:
Creating a great university for Indianapolis, Indiana, and the world:
An IUPUI Timeline
text.text: IUPUI was established in 1969 as a merger of Indiana University and Purdue University campuses in Indianapolis in response to a challenge by the city’s mayor to build a great state university. In the years since then, IUPUI has grown rapidly to meet the higher-education needs of the city, state, and world. It has become the premier urban research university in Indiana. IUPUI can trace its roots back to 1891, when Indiana University first offered lectures in Indianapolis. But many of the schools that became parts of IUPUI predate that event. IUPUI has a rich history that stretches far into the past. This timeline shows the development of IUPUI, first from 1969 to the present. Later, it will outline the nineteenth-century roots of IUPUI and its many parts.

media.caption: Florence Griffith sets the 100 meter world-record for women.
media.credit: Florence Griffith sets the 100 meter world-record for women.

text.headline: Florence Griffith Joyner broke the women’s 100m world record at IUPUI Track Stadium.
text.text: At the United States Olympic track and field trials held in the Michael Carroll Track and Field Stadium, Florence Griffith Joyner broke the women's world's record in one of the 100-meter-dash heats.
text.secondary_headline: One of The Fastest in The World
text.secondary_text: Her time of 10.49 seconds firmly established Carroll Stadium’s track as one of the fastest in the world. Some observers believe the effort was wind-aided, but readings at the event did not record an impermissible wind speed. Since 1988, many female sprinters have tried but failed to surpass her time. Her 100-meter world record is considered one that is unlikely to be broken any time soon.

media.caption: Education/Social Work building groundbreaking, 1980 UA24-003729
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Groundbreaking event for Education/Social Work building and Natatorium building
text.text: University and city grandees gathered to break ground for a new building to house the School of Education and the School of Social Work. The groundbreaking also signaled the beginning of construction of the Natatorium building on the south side of New York Street.
text.secondary_text: Continuing the decades-long effort to consolidate IUPUI's academic programs on the near-west-side campus, assembled leaders lifted ceremonial shovelfuls to begin construction. The new building would allow the School of Education to move from their 902 North Meridian Street location in the Marott Building, where they had sojourned since 1971. The School of Social Work would be able to move out of a crowded Cavanaugh Hall. As well, the School of Physical Education would be able to move from their west 64th Street location to downtown. The two buildings, Education/Social Work and the Natatorium, would be connected by a pedestrian tunnel over New York Street, as well as connect to the Business/SPEA building. Total cost for the two buildings was set at $16.6 million.

media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Report issued on Intercollegiate Athletics for IUPUI and IU Regional Campuses
text.text: In 1973, an IU system-wide committee prepared a report providing guidance for the creation of intercollegiate athletics programs at IUPUI and the regional campuses. The aim was to provide athletic opportunities for students on all IU campuses.

text.headline: IUPUI Faculty Council approved PULS
text.text: In 1991, after long consideration, IUPUI administrators and faculty established a Commission on General Education to "oversee development of a centrally coordinated approach to general education for undergraduates at IUPUI." This arose from the fact that the different schools comprising IUPUI followed different models and lacked a common expectation for undergraduate learning.
text.secondary_text: In the coming years, the commission, with the input from hundreds of IUPUI faculty and administrators, wrestled with developing a common view of general education for IUPUI's undergraduates. Along the way, IUPUI leaders received advice from the North Central Association accreditors to focus on key outcomes for general education that could be assessed meaningfully. In 1993, the commission developed eight Principles of Undergraduate Learning: higher order thinking; critical thinking; intellectual adaptability; self awareness; collaborative learning; co-curricular learning; understanding diversity, and service learning. In 1994, during discussions to merge the IUPUI School of Liberal Arts and the School of Science (a merger which did not occur), school leaders developed a condensed list of five principles of undergraduate learning in the course of considering a potential core curriculum. The faculty governance bodies of the two schools approved this condensed form in 1998.
text.tertiary_text: Meanwhile, discussions occurred widely across the larger campus regarding principles of undergraduate learning. By early 1998, the five Principles adopted by Liberal Arts and Science became six, with "understanding society and culture" and "values and ethics" divided into separate principles. The IUPUI Faculty Council approved the six Principles of Undergraduate Learning at its meeting of May 7, 1998. In the following years, work to incorporate the PULS into the curricula of all undergraduate programs commenced. While the PULS served IUPUI well, in 2018 the IUPUI Faculty Council replaced them with "IUPUI+," or "PLUS," which is a refinement and updating of the original principles.

media.caption: IUPUI Faculty Council Minutes 1970-1971
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IUPUI Faculty Council approved recommendation of Athl. Affairs Committee (AAC) to introduce intercollegiate sports
text.text: The IUPUI Faculty Council, the faculty governance body of the campus, approved the recommendation of its Athletic Affairs Committee to engage in intercollegiate sports competition.
text.secondary_text: The group argued that IUPUI join the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) as soon as possible, noting that "intercollegiate sports were necessary to complete the University's relationship to the community at large and to its alumni," and that sports would provide "positive morale" and "help develop an identification with the institution."

media.caption: Normal College team that won IUPUI intramural championship, 1970 (P. Nicholas Kellum, at right)
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Nick Kellum took IUPUI intramural men's basketball team to IU regional campus basketball tourney
text.text: IUPUI intercollegiate athletics began on March 6, 1971. Its origin was inauspicious and unplanned, not unlike many aspects of IUPUI's development.
text.secondary_text: However, as has typically been the IUPUI experience, from modest beginnings grew great things. The 1969 merger of Purdue and Indiana University campuses in the state capital brought together academic units spread all over Indianapolis. Neither IU-Indianapolis nor the Purdue-Indianapolis Extension had intercollegiate athletics programs. Nowhere in the merger was there any thought about sports at IUPUI. Early administrators worked to consolidate disparate campuses as quickly as possible into the near-westside location, and while intercollegiate sports received the attention of the influential Goals and Objectives Committee of 1971, other issues took priority. At first, IUPUI contented itself with a lively intramural sports program under the direction of P. Nicholas ("Nick") Kellum, an instructor in the Normal College (later the IU School of Physical Education). Meanwhile, in the early 1970s and with the blessing of the president's office in Bloomington, various regional campuses in the IU system around the state began to test the intercollegiate-athletics waters. Several campuses established men's basketball teams and competed with other schools around the state and region. In 1970-1971, the Indiana University-Kokomo men's team compiled an enviable record in games against other IU regionals, Purdue's regional campuses, the Indiana State University-Evansville team, and even the Grissom Air Force base team. IUK announced it would host a four-team IU-regional campus tournament on March 6, 1971, to feature IUK, IUPU-Fort Wayne, IU-Southeast, and IU-South Bend. But IU-South Bend bowed out of the tournament at the last minute. IUPUI came to the rescue.
text.tertiary_text: In January 1971, Nick Kellum's IUPUI intramural men's basketball tournament had crowned as campus champions a team of students from the Normal College. Thus, when Kellum received a call from the IUK coach asking if he could supply a replacement team for the regional tournament, he turned to the intramural champions and entered them in the Kokomo tourney to replace the IU-South Bend team. Kellum appointed himself coach for the team, with Normal College Professor Dr. Rudolph R. Schreiber listed in the tournament program as "Rep." The program and the IUK student newspaper both identified the team as the Normal College IUPUI team, which had no other team name. The first matchup that Saturday began at 12:30pm in a high-school gym in Kokomo and pitted IUK against the IUPUI Normal College players. The contest between an IUK "Little Red" team with a 19 wins and 4 losses record and a pick-up squad was lopsided. The hosts quickly outplaying the visitors. The halftime score was 56 to 32; at the final buzzer it was IUK 114, IUPUI 75. According to the (unnamed) writer for the IUK student newspaper, The Student Voice, the Normal College players were "small but husky." The leading IUPUI player was Shelton Oakes, "who muscled his way for twenty points and 11 rebounds... He didn't get much help from anyone else though and that was the story of the game." The IUK coach used his bench extensively, "substituting platoon style, five a side." After a few hours of rest to lick their wounds, the IUPUI boys played their second game of the day against IUPU-Fort Wayne, the losers of a first-round match-up against IU-Southeast. The 6:30pm tip-off saw IUPUI rally and prevail in overtime over the Mastodons 82-79. The IUK sports reporter termed the result an upset. The IUPUI players thus took home the third-place trophy. The Normal College players who constituted the IUPUI team were: Mike Carr; Ralph Scott; Craig Marshall; Steve Davis, Shelton Oakes; Joe Lentz; Ron Foley; Joe Stewart; Tom Steele; John Schrock; Jeff Vessely; Dave Younce; Tom Fox, and Chris Lawrie. Jeff Vessely later joined the faculty of the School of Physical Education and Tourism Management and served as a department chair and dean. This competition escaped the notice of the two student newspapers at IUPUI, Onomatopoeia of the "Downtown Campus" and the 38th Street campus's Component. Partly for this reason, little is known about IUPUI's participation in the IUK tournament and the origins of IUPUI intercollegiate competiton. From these humble roots the IUPUI athletic program developed. Programs for men and women soon began. IUPUI joined the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA), later switching to the National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA) Division II and still later NCAA Division I. Starting out by fielding an unnamed team, IUPUI players later were known as the Metros, and later still the Jaguars.

media.caption: Hugh A. Wolf, 1984 UA24-008942
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IUPUI Athletics Advisory Committee voted to apply for NCAA Division II
text.text: The Athletics Advisory Committee, a body created by Chancellor Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., to develop policies to govern IUPUI athletics, recommended that IUPUI apply for NCAA Division II status.
text.secondary_text: Hugh A. Wolf, chair of the committee, prepared an application and submitted it to Indiana University Athletic Director Paul Dietzel for preliminary approval. The Bloomington administrator, with the input of IU president John W. Ryan, denied the request, stating that the application did not follow guidelines for IU regional campuses. (This decision ignored the fact that since 1974 IUPUI was no longer a regional campus but a "core campus" with IU-Bloomington.)
text.tertiary_text: Other deficiencies noted in the application were that IUPUI had an Athletics Advisory Committee, not the specified Athletic Affairs Committee, and that IUPUI had submitted a six-year plan rather than the requested five-year plan. More substantively, IUPUI lacked adequate funding for its athletics program, owing in part to IUPUI student fees going to pay for athletics programs in Bloomington. These hurdles to joining NCAA Division II prompted IUPUI leaders to apply instead for membership in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA).

media.caption: IUPUI baseball team, 1994 394-5607-052
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IUPUI Metros baseball team played first game as a varsity team
text.text: In their first competition as a varsity team, the IUPUI Metros baseball team defeated Purdue University-Northwest 23-11 in a game played in Michigan City.
text.secondary_text: The team also won the second game of the double header. In 1978 IUPUI fielded a club team and competed against varsity teams from other colleges. Baseball replaced golf as a varsity men's sport and joined basketball, and tennis in National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) competition. In the following years Metros baseball teams performed well in NAIA play. But in the 1990s when IUPUI attained National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA) Division II and Division I status, the team managed only one winning season (1994). IUPUI administrators dropped baseball in 2001.

media.caption: Wishard Hospital burn ward dedication, 1977 377-0195-003
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Wishard Memorial Hospital burn unit dedicated
text.text: Dignitaries of the Indiana University School of Medicine and Wishard Memorial Hospital, the county hospital for Marion County run by the School of Medicine, dedicated a new thirteen-bed burn unit in Wishard.
text.secondary_text: The unit, only the second of its kind in Indiana, would serve patients who required specialized care. The director of the unit was Dr. John Ronald Mayer, a plastic surgeon and assistant professor of surgery in the School of Medicine, who noted that the unit would serve patients from all over Indiana. In 1975, the IU Medical Center and city government agreed that the School of Medicine would take over medical management of Marion County General Hospital, soon renamed Wishard Memorial Hospital. The new burn unit was one of several improvements that came about from the new management arrangement.

media.caption: Dr. Jan Jansen performs a bone marrow transplant, 1985 485-2185-039
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Indiana’s first bone marrow transplant program opened at Riley Hospital for Children.
text.text: The IU School of Medicine bone marrow transplant program at Riley Hospital was the twelfth one established in the United States.
text.secondary_text: Bone marrow treatments were developed in the 1960s for treating severe noncancerous blood and bone marrow diseases. These diseases, however, are rare. By the 1980s, bone marrow treatments most often were used to treat various forms of leukemia, a malignant disease characterized by the rapid multiplication of white blood cells. In some instances, a bone marrow transplant halts this abnormal growth. Dr. Jan Jansen performed the first transplant at Riley. Dr. Arthur J. Provisor, an associate professor of pediatric hematology and oncology, served as coordinator for pediatrics. Although the program resided at Riley, it accommodated children and adults.
text.tertiary_text: During the first year of the program fewer than 30 patients received transplants, but it expanded quickly to treat 50 to 60 patients per year. The program later moved to University Hospital and was renamed the IU Bone Marrow & Stem Cell Transplantation Program. With scientific advances, three different types of transplants became available, including cord blood transplants pioneered by IU School of Medicine’s Hal Broxmeyer. By 2015–2016, the program performed nearly 400 bone marrow and stem cell transplants per year.

text.headline: The Encyclopedia of Forensic Sciences, edited by Dr. Jay A. Siegel, is published.
text.text: Founding director of the IUPUI Forensic and Investigative Sciences Program, Dr. Jay A. Siegel served as editor of the Encyclopedia of Forensic Sciences because he was a leading expert in the field.
text.secondary_text: Before it appeared, forensic scientists had no comprehensive reference that covered core theories, methods, techniques, and applications that they use in the field and in the laboratory. The encyclopedia informed forensic scientists about the protocols and procedures they need to use as they collect evidence from crime scenes and analyze it in the laboratory. The encyclopedia examined the limitations of these protocols and procedures as well.
text.tertiary_text: Siegel also was a member of a National Academy of Science Committee that authored an external review of forensic science in the United States and outlined how it should develop. This study has been very influential in shaping reform in forensics. Siegel was a Distinguished Fellow in the American Academy of Forensic Sciences and received its one of its highest honors, the Paul L. Kirk Award. Each year, the IUPUI Forensic and Investigative Sciences Program awards its top student the Forensic Science Dr. Jay A. Siegel Award.

media.caption: Prof. Walter Nance preparing fingerprints of non-identical twins, nd UA24-000353
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: The Indiana University School of Medicine received a $711,813 grant from the US Department of Health, Education, and Welfare (HEW) to establish a major center for research in genetic diseases.
text.text: The IU School of Medicine (IUSM) was the tenth center for research in genetic diseases that HEW funded in the country and the first in the Midwest.
text.secondary_text: The center was housed at Riley Hospital for Children, where an existing genetics clinic already treated approximately 1,000 patients a year. The clinic was established at Riley because hereditary conditions were the leading causes of infant mortality. Statistics revealed that 7 to 8 percent of the US population suffered from genetic diseases. In 1974, Dr. Walter E. Nance, professor of medical genetics, became director of the new center. Its early researchers concentrated in such areas as hereditary deafness, identical twins and their families, variations in human proteins and enzymes, chromosome abnormalities, the effectiveness of genetic counseling, and the roles of chromosomes in human genes.
text.tertiary_text: From the very beginning, Dr. P. Michael Conneally, who discovered the genetic marker for Huntington’s Disease, was a key member of the faculty involved in genetic research at the center. Other significant grants followed, setting the stage for Indiana University to take a leading role in genetic research. The Center for Medical Genomics at IUSM provides state-of-the-art technology, research, and services. Department of Medical and Molecular Genetics Faculty provide counseling for a variety of hereditary conditions and birth defects, and by 2015, IUSM board-certified geneticists served more than 2,000 people per year.

media.caption: Dancers in Hideaway, 1983 UA24-003146n
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Hideaway cafe closed
text.text: Students were dismayed to learn that a favorite campus resort was to close.
text.secondary_text: The Hideaway, a cafe in the basement of the Blake Street Library, served burgers, snacks, coffee, and pop to hungry scholars. But library staff needed space to install microfilm readers and printers. The cafe also was a venue for a variety of cultural events through the years.

media.caption: Wishard Memorial Hospital, 1975 UA24-004647
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: The Health and Hospital Corporation of Marion County, Indiana, and Indiana University signed an agreement for the IU School of Medicine to provide management of Marion County General Hospital.
text.text: With the initial two-year trial agreement, the IU School of Medicine (IUSM) took over all management and professional services of Marion County General Hospital, including patient care, teaching, and research activities.
text.secondary_text: At the same time, the hospital was renamed Wishard Memorial Hospital. The agreement was in the “best interest of both parties.” IUSM had for several years maintained cooperative relationships with the county hospital. Despite efforts to attract paying patients with passage of Medicare and Medicaid in 1965, General Hospital primarily cared for an indigent population. It had a bad reputation and struggled financially.
text.tertiary_text: These problems hampered IUSM’s ability to provide quality educational, clinical, and research opportunities. IUSM management improved Wishard’s services. The hospital began generating more income and its accreditation improved, while IUSM students had access to a full range of patients. In 2013, the 150-year-old health care entity experienced another rebirth with the opening of the Sidney & Lois Eskenazi Hospital, a brand new, state-of-the-art facility. At Eskenazi, IUSM continues to provide quality clinical care to the city's citizens.

media.caption: P. Michael Conneally, 1983 UA24-005743
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: P. Michael Conneally, professor of genetics at the IU School of Medicine, and other investigators discovered the genetic marker for Huntington’s disease.
text.text: Conneally worked with researchers from Massachusetts General Hospital and Johns Hopkins Hospital to make this breakthough discovery.
text.secondary_text: A world leader in human genetics, Conneally began his research on the disease in the late 1960s. He was a member of the Congressional Commission on Huntington’s Disease in the 1970s, and he conducted annual research trips to Venezuela, where the disease is particularly prevalent. Conneally understood very early the value of DNA markers for Huntington’s Disease research.
text.tertiary_text: In the 1970s, he began collecting gene samples from Huntington Disease families across the Midwest in his search for the gene. These samples provided the foundation for the National Huntington’s Disease Research Roster at Indiana University, which was established in 1979. Containing family trees and demographic data, the Roster linked researchers, patients, and family members to promote research projects that identify treatments and cures. In addition to isolating its genetic marker, Conneally participated in mapping the actual Huntington’s Disease gene in 1993.

media.caption: Dr. Douglas P. Zipes, 1979 UA24-08994
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Cardiologist Douglas Zipes invented the implantable transvenous cardioverter to correct heart arrhythmia.
text.text: An expert in heart arrhythmias, Zipes developed the cardioverter, in collaboration with Medtronic, the world’s largest medical device company.
text.secondary_text: It was the first device of its kind. With the cardioverter, Zipes implemented his concept of delivering an electric shock over a catheter to stop ventricular tachycardia. The cardioverter could be introduced via a catheter into the heart. This groundbreaking medical device corrected life-threatening abnormal rapid cardiac rhythms. Cardioverters have become a primary tool for preventing sudden cardiac death from this cause.
text.tertiary_text: A renowned cardiologist, Zipes served as Director of the Cardiology Division and Krannert Institute of Cardiology at the Indiana University School of Medicine from 1994 to 2005. He was founding editor of the Journal of Cardiovascular Electrophysiology and Heart Rhythm. He has earned awards from such organizations as the American Heart Association, the American College of Cardiology, and the American College of Physicians. The Medtronic Zipes Chair in Cardiology and the Joan and Douglas Zipes Visiting Professorship at Indiana University School of Medicine also honor his accomplishments as a researcher and pioneer in cardiac pacing.

media.caption: Dr. Lawrence H. Einhorn, 1977 UA24-006244
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IU School of Medicine distinguished professor, Lawrence H. Einhorn MD introduced new drug therapies curing patients with testicular cancer.
text.text: At the time Einhorn treated his first patient with Cisplatin, a platinum-based chemotherapy, it was an experimental drug. He combined it with two other drugs with spectacular results.
text.secondary_text: Before the “Einhorn Regimen,” the cure rate for testicular cancer was only 10 percent. Radical surgery was the best hope for those who had the disease. In the early 1970s, Einhorn’s colleague at the IU School of Medicine, John P. Donohue, was widely acknowledged as the word leader in performing this surgical cure in the early 1970s.
text.tertiary_text: He achieved a 20 percent survival rate when the disease was caught in its earliest stages. Einhorn’s drug therapy was transformative. It increased the overall cure rate for testicular cancer to 95 percent. From having a nearly uniformly fatal prognosis, testicular cancer became a curable form of cancer. Einhorn continued to refine treatment. No matter how far advanced the disease the goal is always cure.

media.caption: Paul R. Bippen, 1977 UA24-005286
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Paul R. Bippen Appointed Director at IUPUI-Columbus Center
text.text: IUPUI chancellor Dr. Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., named Dr. Paul R. Bippen director of the IUPUI-Columbus Center.
text.secondary_text: Bippen had served as interim director of the center since 1976, and before that he had been assistant to Indiana University's chancellor for regional programs and assistant to the IUPUI dean of the faculties.

text.headline: IU School of Nursing Center for Nursing Research Opened
text.text: Indiana University School of Nursing celebrated the grand opening of the school's Center for Nursing Research.
text.secondary_text: The opening was recognition of the significant role of research in nursing scholarship and teaching in the school, as well as growing external support for faculty research efforts on topics such as stress, families with children with epilepsy or elders with Alzheimer's, migrant families, reducing child mortality, and others. The Center afforded larger and better facilities for research and study in the existing Nursing building.

media.caption: Darrell L. Bailey, 1998 898-7252-007
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IUPUI opens state-of-the-art computer music laboratory
text.text: IUPUI opened its new computer music laboratory, a joint effort of the Indiana University School of Music at IUPUI and campus computing services.
text.secondary_text: The lab afforded students the opportunity to compose and perform music employing a wide range of computer equipment and software. Darrell L. Bailey, director of the IUPUI music program and designer of the lab, explained that students would be able to learn the latest music technologies that were "revolutionizing the music performing and recording fields." Using new technologies, students could compose music or mix previous compositions in new combinations.
text.tertiary_text: "Student interest in the lab already is extraordinary," said Bailey. He added that the lab was the "largest and most technologically advanced in the nation" and afforded students interested in music technologies the best training opportunities in preparation to enter the field. The lab resided in the Mary Cable Building, a former public-school building bought by IUPUI to house classes and offices.

text.headline: The Indiana University School of Dentistry created the Division of Community Dentistry.
text.text: Having a long tradition of community service and involvement in dental public health, the IU School of Dentistry established the Division of Community Dentistry to increase its community involvement by integrating community service and dental public health activities into its curriculum.
text.secondary_text: Through the Division of Community Dentistry, the school works to interact with its neighbors and offers students and faculty the opportunity to learn about the needs of an increasingly diverse population in Indiana.

media.caption: Archivist Jeannette M. Matthew (right) and students hold student newspapers, 1976 UA24-006860
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: The Sagamore, IUPUI student newspaper, established
text.text: In July 1971, a group of IUPUI students, faculty, and administrators met to draft a plan for a single student publication.
text.secondary_text: An observer deemed the event a "major step toward making IPI [what many called IUPUI in its early days] a completely unified university." IUPUI students published the first issue on October 5, 1971. Prior to the IUPUI merger, the different Indiana University and Purdue University campuses in Indianapolis each featured its own student newspaper. The Purdue University-Indianapolis Extension campus on 38th Street had The Component (a take-off of the West Lafayette student newspaper, The Exponent).
text.tertiary_text: Students of Indiana University in Indianapolis had published several student papers through the years, including The Capitol Student and The Indianapolis Student, along with student newsletters like The Peace Reporter. After the merger, downtown-campus IUPUI students published the ingeniously titled Onomatopoeia. The plan for a single student publication resulted in The Sagamore, a newspaper that ran from 1971 to its demise in 2009. Starting out a weekly, The Sagamore periodically published three times a week during the school year and featured lively editorials, reporting, and original art. For one year in the 2000s, the newspaper ran an original sex column. The comic strip "Doonesbury" ran in The Sagamore long before the Indianapolis Star was bold enough to publish it. Today, student journalists publish The Campus Citizen online.

media.caption: Riley Hospital construction, 1985 UA24-004145
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Indiana's first trauma center designed specifically for children opened at the James Whitcomb Riley Hospital for Children on the Indiana University Medical Center campus.
text.text: Since it opened in 1924, Riley Hospital had been the first and only hospital in the state to offer an emergency room for children.
text.secondary_text: With the new pediatric trauma center, Riley laid claim to having the first to follow all recommended guidelines for treating trauma in children in the nation. Such centers are necessary because the care of children suffering trauma, from burns to spinal cord injuries, is different from the way traumas such treatment is approached in adults. The center allowed Riley staff to provide effective treatment to double or triple the number of children it had before. By 2001, the center treated nearly 14,000 children per year.
text.tertiary_text: Forty percent of those children came from counties outside of Indianapolis. The trauma center allows 24-hour access to pediatric radiology, anesthesiology, surgery, critical care, laboratory services, under the care of board-certified pediatric physicians and surgeons for children throughout the state. In 2018, it could boast that pediatric patients were within reach of a team of “world-renowned emergency physicians and specialized surgeons, nurses and social works, critical care doctors and chaplains” within 15 minutes. Riley Hospital continued to be the only one in the state with a certified Level 1 Pediatric Trauma Center.

media.caption: Aerial view of IU Natatorium, 1984 784-1977-134
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: World records set at Natatorium during Olympic trials.
text.text: The Indiana University Natatorium, opened in 1982, firmly established its reputation as a world-class pool when, during the 1984 US Swimming Olympic trials, US swimmer Rick Carey broke the world record in the Men's 200 meter backstroke, with a time of 1:58.86.
text.secondary_text: John Moffet broke the world record in the 100 meter breast stroke, with a time of 1:02.13, and Pablo Morales broke the world record in the 100 meter butterfly with a time of 53.38.

text.headline: First Chancellor of IUPUI
text.text: Dr. Maynard K. Hine, D.D.S. was named the first Chancellor of IUPUI. With his previous administrative experience in the IU School of Dentistry, Hine strategically worked with the faculty and adminstration to develop specific goals for the future of IUPUI.

media.caption: Natatorium interior, 1982 UA24-004072
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IUPUI dedicated the IU Natatorium, the IU Track and Field Stadium and the IU School of Physical Education.
text.text: The summer of 1982 saw the completion of the track stadium (now called Michael A. Carroll Stadium) and the Natatorium shortly in advance of the National Sports Festival IV (July 23–31, 1982).
text.secondary_text: The facilities arose as the result of years of close coordination between IUPUI and Indianapolis leaders to position the city as a sporting destination. The track and the pool proved to be fast, making them popular with runners and swimmers. Carroll stadium hosted track and field events for the 1987 Pan American Games, the 2001 World Police and Fire Games, and several USA Track and Field and NCAA Championships.
text.tertiary_text: During the 1988 US Olympic Trials held at the stadium, Florence Griffith-Joyner set the 100-meters world record for women. By 2009, fifteen world records and 101 American records had been set at the Indiana University Natatorium. Events hosted in IUPUI facilities brought national and international attention to Indianapolis and IUPUI.

media.caption: Members of IUPUI Staff Council, 1997 497-6870-002
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: First Meeting of IUPUI Staff Council
text.text: The IUPUI Staff Council, the self-governance body for non-academic staff of IUPUI, met for the first time on August 8, 1979.
text.secondary_text: The body, representing many thousands of employees, had its origins in efforts begun in 1974 by the Advisory Committee to the IUPUI Faculty Council's Staff Affairs Committee. Continued development of the idea was contingent on passage of a 1975 law in the Indiana General Assembly allowing for collective bargaining among Indiana University workers. In 1978 campus leadership gave its blessing to the creation of a Staff Council to represent non-academic employees not represented by a union. The first elections occurred in the following year.
text.tertiary_text: At its first meeting in 1979, Dean of the Faculties Dr. Edward C. Moore reiterated that campus leadership gave its full support to the Staff Council, adding that administrative staff for the Faculty Council would also serve Staff Council. Since then, Staff Council has had an important voice in campus affairs and in advancing IUPUI.

media.caption: GO Committee Preliminary Report, 1973
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Goals and Objectives Committee Preliminary Report on future development of IUPUI
text.text: In April 1973, the Goals and Objectives Committee, chaired by Prof. James P. White of the Indiana University School of Law-Indianapolis, released a report in which it recommended actions leaders should take to develop the campus.
text.secondary_text: These included development of undergraduate, graduate, and professional programs, reorganizing administrative units, as well as improving campus housing and other facilities. The report was influential and shaped administrators' actions for many years.

media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Jinx the Jaguar appears at IUPUI Homecoming
text.text: Jinx the Jaguar made his appearance at an IUPUI Homecoming.
text.secondary_text: The day featured a doubleheader of women's and men's basketball games against Valparaiso University teams. The lovable IUPUI mascot, introduced not long before as IUPUI moved up to National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA) Division I, cavorted with alums and students at pre-game events. He then led fans in efforts to "Jinx the Crusaders." Alas, despite Jinx's efforts the Jaguars fell to their opponents that day. The women's team lost 67-58, and the men succumbed 75-58.

text.headline: First IUPUI Commencement
text.text: First IUPUI commencement held at the Indiana State Fairground Coliseum, granting 1,535 degrees.

text.headline: Spring break extended an extra week due to national energy crisis and coal miner strike
text.text: In late 1977 and into the New Year, international politics sent petroleum prices skyward.
text.secondary_text: As well, coal miners in the United States went on strike, creating coal shortages for power producers reliant on the fossil fuel. IUPUI chancellor Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., instituted energy conservation practices to reduce university costs as well as to reduce the strain on supplies of coal needed to heat campus buildings. Making the situation dire was the severe cold and heavy snows that central Indiana experienced in February. Staff, faculty, and students felt minus-20-degrees-fahrenheit temperatures. Demand for coal to generate electricity and steam heat spiked.
text.tertiary_text: In late February Irwin announced that spring break, to start on March 3, would be extended one week to continue through March 20. In the meantime, campus staff would turn down the heat in campus buildings to 50-55 degrees to save money and minimize coal demand. As well, office workers who continued to work during spring break moved into temporary digs. The Green Sheet, the campus newsletter, quipped that it was time to "shiver and shake."

media.credit: https://www.rileychildrens.org/connections/when-dr-schreiner-and-a-motor-home-sped-through-indiana-to-rescue-dying-babies

text.headline: Riley Hospital for Children began operation of one of the first mobile Newborn Intensive Care Units.
text.text: Pioneering Riley neonatologist Edwin L. Gresham designed this special ambulance.
text.secondary_text: Few, if any, life support vehicles equipped especially for transporting seriously ill or premature infants existed at this time. Gresham’s basic unit was a converted recreational vehicle, equipped as a mini ICU, with incubators, ventilators, monitors, warmers, centrifuge, and blood gas analyzer. Dr. Richard Schreiner, who later became chairman of the IU School of Medicine Department of Pediatrics and physician in chief of Riley Hospital, was the neonatologist who first manned the vehicle. With the mobile Newborn Intensive Care Unit, he could reach babies within a 75-mile radius of the IU Medical Center.
text.tertiary_text: The ambulance could accommodate up to three infants at a time and made about 200 runs a year. Before this special vehicle was available, ambulance teams could only stabilize and prevent deterioration of an infant’s condition on the way to the hospital. The mobile Newborn Intensive Care Unit provided Schreiner with the equipment necessary to initiate lifesaving and life-supportive procedures immediately when they arrived where they had been called. High-tech ambulance replaced this first unit bringing lifesaving emergency care to infants throughout the state.

text.headline: Men's basketball won Mid-Continent conference tourney, went to NCAA Division I tourney
text.text: Having won their conference tournament, the IUPUI Jaguars advanced to the NCAA Division I tournament for the first time.
text.secondary_text: Seeded sixteen in the regional played in Minneapolis, the Jaguars lost in the first round to number-one-seeded University of Kentucky Wildcats 95-64 in a game played March 21, 2003. The Jaguars were coached by Ron Hunter.

text.headline: Grace Norman and Austin Pruitt break distance world records at Carroll Stadium in 800-, 1,500-, and 5,000- meter events.

media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Black Student Union adopted its first constitution
text.text: Members of the Black Student Union adopted a constitution to govern its future meetings and activities and elected officers.
text.secondary_text: According to The Component, the student newspaper of IUPUI's 38th Street campus, the organization aimed to assist black students "with any problems they encounter in achieving a higher education." Black students received automatic membership, but the group welcomed all students who shared its goals. The newspaper reported that the BSU would organize clean-up campaigns and establish scholarships. During the 1970s, the BSU became the most active and important student organization in IUPUI, organizing conferences, meetings, and other events.
text.tertiary_text: It advocated for African-American residents in the neighborhood onto which IUPUI was superimposed, and advised campus leaders on ways to address the issues of racial discrimination and social justice.

media.caption: IUPUI Strategic Plan, 2014
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Our Commitment to Indiana and Beyond: IUPUI Strategic Plan
text.text: IUPUI chancellor Charles Bantz launched a new IUPUI Strategic Plan for the campus.
text.secondary_text: The plan was developed by a large number of persons under the overall direction of Nasser Paydar, then executive vice chancellor and chief academic officer of IUPUI. The plan advanced ten strategic goals with three broad priorities: 1. The success of our students; 2. advances in health and life sciences, and 3. contributions to the well-being of the citizens of Indianapolis, the state of Indiana, and beyond.

text.headline: IUPUI and Ivy Tech signed agreement to coordinate admissions and registration
text.text: IUPUI chancellor Gerald L. Bepko and Indiana Vocational and Technical College chancellor Meredith L. Carter signed an agreement to work together to assist students to progress through their post-secondary education.
text.secondary_text: The institutions would cooperate to streamline student counseling in matters relative to admissions, course selection, cross-registration, and more. The schools would use new computer technologies in these efforts. IUPUI and Ivy Tech had long cooperated through the Consortium on Urban Education (CUE). The new agreement advanced their collaboration, with plans to investigate additional paths to cooperate to serve students’ educational needs.

media.caption: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives
media.credit: Homecoming court, 1978 278--426-003

text.headline: IUPUI Celebrates First Homecoming
text.text: IUPUI students had competed in intercollegiate athletics for several years. IUPUI's first intercollegiate athletic competition occurred in 1971 when the winning men's intramurals basketball team played in an intercollegiate tournament.
text.secondary_text: The first Metros men's basketball team organized in 1972. It would seem, then, that no one thought to organize homecoming events during those first seasons until IUPUI joined the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) conference in 1978. Having decided to celebrate homecoming, IUPUI students intended to be different. As the Sagamore, the IUPUI student newspaper, reported, the student homecoming committee scheduled IUPUI's event to occur during the "midterm doldrums." They thought it "important to generate a united campus interest and promote an identity of our own," separate from Indiana University-Bloomington and Purdue University-West Lafayette.
text.tertiary_text: Festivities began at noon on game day, when team players, coaches, and cheerleaders led a pep rally in The Hideaway, the cafe in the basement of the Blake Street Library. The fifteen candidates for Homecoming Queen appeared, from which students voted for six finalists. In addition, the committee announced the winner of the "Metro for a Night" competition, the winner of which could sit on the team bench during the game. The excitement moved to the State Fairgrounds Coliseum, when the New York Street Singers, one of the campus choirs, performed a pre-game concert. Tip-off for the game against the NCAA Division II Indiana State University-Evansville (now the University of Southern Indiana) Eagles took place at 8pm. The Metros upset the Eagles 78-77. During halftime, a local sportscaster crowned Debbie Mincy, representing the School of Science, Homecoming Queen. Both students and IUPUI alums bought tickets to attend the game for $1. A homecoming dance at the Union Building on campus followed the game and continued until 2am. Students gained free admission if they showed their game ticket.

text.headline: Students and faculty organize protest against university investment in apartheid-era South Africa
text.text: The Indianapolis South Africa Committee (ISAC), a group of IUPUI students and faculty, announced their intention to picket the upcoming meeting of the Indiana University Board of Trustees.
text.secondary_text: They wished to protest the university's investment in corporations that did business in South Africa, whose government implemented racist Apartheid policies against native black Africans and other persons of color. University security measures impeded a reporter of the Sagamore, the IUPUI student newspaper, from attending the March 3 meeting. As well, the reporter learned subsequently that the board had met in secret the previous day to avoid protesters.
text.tertiary_text: The gathering on March 3 was a short one at which trustees merely announced their support for the 1977 Sullivan principles of corporate social responsibility when doing business in South Africa.

media.caption: IUPUI Metros basketball team in action in NAIA tournament, Kansas City, 1985 385-2150-001
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Men’s basketball team won NAIA District 21 championship
text.text: IUPUI Metros men’s basketball team defeated Tri-State University 71-68 to win the District 21 championship.
text.secondary_text: The victory was the team’s twelfth in a row and entered them in the NAIA National Championships in the Kemper Arena in Kansas City, Missouri. On March 14 the Metros, 31st of 32, lost to the number 2-seeded Univ. of Wisconsin-Stevens Point 71-61. The team completed a 21 win, 15 loss season, coached by Bob Lovell.

text.headline: First world record set at IU Natatorium
text.text: Just weeks after the Indiana University Natatorium was completed, swimmer Stephen K. Lundquist set the stage for the IU Natatorium to earn its reputation as a world-class pool with his world record time in the Men's 100 meter breaststroke.
text.secondary_text: Lundquist went on to break his own world record several times, until US swimmer John Moffet won the event during the 1984 US Olympic Trials at the IU Natatorium on June 25, 1984, with a time of 1:02.13.

text.headline: Men's baseball discontinued
text.text: IUPUI issued a news release announcing that the university was ending its baseball team.
text.secondary_text: The news came at the end of the baseball team's season, its third in National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA) Division I competition in the Mid-Continent Conference. Earlier in the week, the team's coaches announced their resignations. Then the IUPUI athletic director met with the baseball team players privately to inform them that the university had decided no longer to field a team. The public announcement came two days later. The press statement noted that ending the baseball program would allow IUPUI to "strengthen financially its support of the remaining fourteen sports teams." It explained that the university did not have its own baseball field and had to rent facilities, the only IUPUI team that had to do so. The team played some seasons in Bush Stadium and Victory Field, the venues of the Triple AAA professional team, the Indianapolis Indians. The large number of games (56) and the extensive travel for the team also added significant expense.
text.tertiary_text: The announcement noted that players receiving scholarships would be eligible to receive them for the 2001-2002 academic year. Men's baseball as a varsity sport at IUPUI began in 1979, when the university participated in National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) competition. The team met with success through the NAIA years, but when the IUPUI switched to NCAA play, first Division II, then Division I, the team struggled to achieve winning seasons.

media.caption: Team photo published in Sagamore, March 13, 1972

text.headline: Men’s basketball team play as Metros in IU-Kokomo tournament
text.text: IUPUI men's basketball team played their first game using the Metros as their team name.
text.secondary_text: The Metros played the Little Reds of Indiana University-Kokomo. The game was a rematch from their meeting of March 1971, when IUPUI sent the winning intramurals-tournament team to play in Kokomo's tournament. IUPUI lost the game. Coached by George Dickison (assisted by intramurals director and Normal College instructor P. Nicholas Kellum), in the next two months the Metros played teams from IU and Purdue University regional campuses, compiling an overall season record of one win and six losses.

text.headline: Inaugural Jagathon Dance Marathon
text.text: The IUPUI Student Foundation hosted the inaugural Jagathon, part of the Indiana University Dance Marathon, to raise money for Riley Hospital for Children on the IUPUI campus.
text.secondary_text: Starting at 3pm on Saturday, February 22, IUPUI students danced 18 hours through the afternoon, night, and into the morning of Sunday, February 24. The event took place in the Union Building, which has since been razed. Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital now occupies the place where the Union Building stood. Thirty IUPUI students danced in the inaugural event and raised just over $2000.
text.tertiary_text: Jagathon has taken place each year since 2002. The event has grown in scope and impact. In 2018, Jagathon raised a record $501,371.24. Overall, Jagathon has raised more $1.25 million for pediatric research at Riley, becoming one of the biggest college dance marathon programs in the United States.

text.headline: IUPUI Faculty Council approved PLUS
text.text: On 5 1, 2018 the IUPUI Faculty Council formally endorsed Profiles of Learning for Undergraduate Success, or IUPUI+ (PLUS).
text.secondary_text: Plus replaced the Principles of Undergraduate Learning (PULs) and the Principles of Co-curricular Learning (PCLs), which governed desired outcomes for IUPUI undergraduate students' experiences both inside and outside the classroom.

media.caption: The Polis Center
media.credit: The Polis Center

text.headline: Founding of The Polis Center
text.text: Established in 1989 to link two types of expertise—academic and practical—for the benefit of communities in Indiana and elsewhere, the center specializes in providing place-based research tools to transform data into usable information for more effective local decision-making.
text.secondary_text: The Polis Center also offers the SAVI online tool—the nation’s largest community information system—to help nonprofits, academia, government, and health organizations assess trends and conditions, identify service gaps, and better target areas of concern based on the social, economic and other demographic realities in more than 2,000 Central Indiana communities. The Polis Center is deeply committed to the development of partnerships and the practical use of advanced technologies. Its collaborative and entrepreneurial nature results in a unique and diverse range of applied projects to strengthen communities in Indiana and beyond.

media.caption: Text of speech by Mayor Richard G. Lugar, 1968
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Indianapolis mayor called for independent state university in city
text.text: Indianapolis mayor Richard G. Lugar gave a speech entitled "A Great University for Greater Indianapolis" broadcast locally on television.
text.secondary_headline: Improve the Quality of Education in Indianapolis
text.secondary_text: It addressed the need for a major public research university in the city. Lugar's address was a blunt and bold threat to the Indiana University and Purdue University leadership to improve the quality and quantity of higher-education opportunities in Indianapolis.
text.tertiary_text: If the university leaders continued to postpone making a decision, he warned, political leaders in the city would pass legislation in the Indiana General Assembly to take their city campuses and form an independent state university. Lugar's speech was symptomatic of widespread frustration with the limited offerings from the extension campuses of IU and Purdue. Since the 1950s the universities had been in talks to create a joint campus in Indianapolis. City leaders had been party to the talks, but university leaders could not agree about how to finance the new entity. In the following days and weeks, TV and newspapers editorialized on Lugar's speech and reinforced his message calling for action. Legislators promised to introduce bills to create a new university for the city. University leaders were thus forced to act to preserve control of their Indianapolis campus assets.

media.caption: Women's Leadership Awards luncheon, 1998 1198-7317-005
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: The Office for Women was created to improve the campus environment for women at IUPUI
text.text: In 1994, Chancellor Gerald Bepko appointed a Task Force on the Status of Women to review data concerning conditions for women at IUPUI.
text.secondary_text: The task force determined that women experienced gender-based harassment, privilege, and discrimination on campus: “IUPUI does not uniformly create and maintain a work and learning environment where diversity is valued and all members of our community can thrive." The IUPUI Office for Women implemented an action agenda for change. As part of that effort, the office created a Commission on Women Steering Committee. Working groups within the steering committee studied such gender issues as child care, pay equity and support equity, recruitment and retention, and sexual harassment. They also investigated how to provide general advice for success and how to shape the learning environment and curricular content. These working groups became very successful.
text.tertiary_text: In 1997, the Pay Equity/Support Equity Working Group performed a campus-wide study of pay equity for full-time faculty and librarians. The Sexual Harassment Working Group prepared a leadership training program for departmental chairs and unit leaders that was presented in March of 1999, and the Child Care Working Group successfully opened the IUPUI Center for Young Children in 2000. The IUPUI Office for Women set out to foster a climate of civility and mutual respect regardless of race, gender, age, or status in the institution. The office still monitors the climate for women and provides direction on campus. It seeks to address the needs of women, to empower them, to create welcoming environments, to tackle gender equity, and to promote a safe campus climate.

text.headline: The student governments of the 38th Street Campus, IU-Circle City Campus, Herron School of Art and the Normal College held a joint meeting.
text.text: The purpose of the meeting was to discuss how the merger would affect their groups.
text.secondary_text: At the meeting, students created the Ad Hoc Committee on Student Solidarity to explore avenues open to students and to draft a new student government.

text.headline: IU School of Law-Indianapolis moved onto the IUPUI Campus
text.text: Indiana University's law school in Indianapolis grew out of mergers of several private law schools that had operated in the city since the nineteenth century.
text.secondary_text: Many of these schools catered to students who worked in downtown offices and city and state government; therefore, they offered classes in the evening. Indiana University merged with the private Indiana Law School in 1944 and operated what many called the "Indianapolis Law School" as an evening division of the IU School of Law in Bloomington. In 1968, the Indianapolis division of the law school obtained its independence from the Bloomington law school and promptly planned to offer a full-time, daytime array of courses.
text.tertiary_text: It took two years of planning to finalize. On September 15, 1969, IU School of Law-Indianapolis commenced its first full-time day program. To accommodate the daytime program, in 1970 the law school moved into a new building at Blackford and New York Streets (later vacated, renovated, and occupied now by the Herron School of Art and Design).

text.headline: The Riley Hospital Parent Care Unit opened.
text.text: Dr. Morris Green, chairman of the Department of Pediatrics and physician in chief of Riley Hospital for Children, created a national model for familly-centered care when he created the Parent Care Unit.
text.secondary_text: Parents could stay round the clock with their children. They also learned necessary treatment procedures to care for their child from pediatricians and nurses.

text.headline: The Undergraduate Campus, consisting of Robert E. Cavanaugh Hall, the Lecture Hall, and the first University Library (now Taylor Hall) opened.

media.caption: MEAP student, 1989 789-3658-029
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: The Minority Engineering Advancement Program (MEAP) was founded.
text.text: The dean of IUPUI’s School of Engineering & Technology, Dr. R. Bruce Renda, created the Minority Engineering Advancement Program (MEAP) to address underrepresentation of minorities in engineering professions.
text.secondary_text: While 11 to 12 percent of the population was African American at the time of its founding, blacks made up only 1.2 percent of practicing professional engineers. MEAP supports and encourages middle school, high school, and college-aged minority students interested in studying and working in engineering. The program consists of summer camps for precollege-aged students and provides scholarships for minority IUPUI students. MEAP activities provide hands-on experience in fields such as mechanical engineering, biomedical engineering, electrical engineering, robotics, and computer science. MEAP was ahead of the curve in computer technology, offering computer science activities as early as 1976.
text.tertiary_text: The program has had great success in promoting and nurturing minority achievement in engineering and college education in general. According to a ten-year tracking study performed by the program in 1989, 90 percent of high school MEAP participants attended college, and 85 percent were studying engineering or a related field. In 1986, a Yale University study recognized MEAP as a model program, citing it as the only one of its kind to offer programs for junior high schoolers. MEAP has taken advantage of IUPUI’s location in both the most diverse and most economically active area of Indiana by gaining the cooperation and financial support of major businesses such as Eli Lilly, Dow Chemical, Ford Motor Company, and RCA. The program exemplifies both IUPUI’s commitment to diversity and its connections to local industry and commerce.

text.headline: Indianapolis Tennis Center opened on the IUPUI campus
text.text: The city of Indianapolis selected the location of the Indianapolis Tennis Center at IUPUI as part of its plan to increase its ties to the campus.
text.secondary_text: As the sport of tennis began attracting more fans, the city of Indianapolis needed a newer, larger venue to continue to host the US Clay Court Championships, which had been held at the Indianapolis Racquet Club since 1969. Built in 1978-1979, the Indianapolis Tennis Center included six courts covered and not used during winter, two courts with 2,000 seats, and a main court with 12,000 seats. The stadium could be used for smaller events and recreational activities, in addition to large events like the Clay Courts. The main court could also be used for other events including concerts, ice skating, and youth hockey. The $4-million plan faced some opposition, but most people felt the large venue could bolster a positive image for the city, while bringing more money downtown.
text.tertiary_text: Private donations funded most of the cost. In 1979, the first US Clay Court Championships held at the center sold more tickets than the tournament ever had. It continued to host the US Clay Courts Championships until 1987. From 1988 to 2009, the Indianapolis Tennis Championships, part of the Association of Tennis Professionals (ATP) Tour, replaced the Clay Courts as its most important tournament. Between 1984 and 2001, the stadium won the United States Tennis Association Facilities Award eleven times. Famous tennis players who played at the Indianapolis Tennis Center included Arthur Ashe, Andre Agassi, and Pete Sampras. Unfortunately, sponsorships for the ATP tournament fell into decline. The Indianapolis Tennis Championships moved out of Indianapolis in 2009. Without the funding that this warm-up event for the US Open provided, the stadium closed. It was demolished in 2010. The 2009 IUPUI master plan looked to redesign this part of campus to integrate it better with downtown Indianapolis and White River State Park.

media.caption: Otis R. Bowen, MD, 1983
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Bowen Research Center announced
text.text: Indiana University School of Medicine announced the creation of the Bowen Research Center to focus on the role of the primary-care physician in health care.
text.secondary_text: The center was named after School of Medicine alumnus, former governor of Indiana, and former secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Dr. Otis R. Bowen, MD. The Bowen Research Center would be housed in the Department of Family Medicine, chaired by Dr. Deborah Allen, MD. Its aim was to develop methods for primary-care physicians in both rural and urban settings to reduce preventable disease and curb health-care costs.
text.tertiary_text: "Doc" Bowen (1918-2013) was born in northern Indiana. He earned a B.A. at Indiana University-Bloomington and the M.D. from the School of Medicine in 1942. After service in the U.S. Army Medical Corps during World War Two, he practiced medicine in Bremen, Indiana while serving in the Indiana House of Representatives in the 1950s and 1960s, becoming speaker of the House in 1967. He only curtailed his medical practice when he ran for governor in 1972. He served two terms, after which he accepted an appointment as clinical professor of family medicine in the School of Medicine.

text.headline: IUPUI softball team took third place in AIAW Midwest regional tourney
text.text: The Metros women's softball team finished in second place in the state AIAW tournament and took third place in the Midwest regional tournament. The team compiled an overall record of 29 wins and 7 losses.

text.headline: IUPUI softball team won state AIAW championship
text.text: The IUPUI women's softball team, coached by P. Nicholas Kellum, won the state Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women (AIAW) championship.
text.secondary_text: The Metros team went on to place fourth in the Midwest tournament. Overall, the team posted 25 wins and 2 losses.

text.headline: IUPUI softball team won NAIA District 21 championship

text.secondary_text: The team went the NAIA National Tournament for the first time, the first IUPUI team to advance to a national tournament. The Metros placed fifth. The team had a 36-10-2 record overall, and 21-2 in NAIA competition. Four members of the team were named to the NAIA All-American teams, three on the first team, one on the second team.
