text.text: After winning the District 21 Tournament for the seventh year in a row, the Metros competed in the NAIA National Tournament and finished in fourth place. The softball team compiled a 48 wins and 19 losses record for the season.

text.headline: IUPUI softball team won NAIA District 21 Tournament
text.text: After winning the district tournament for the eighth year in a row, the Metros softball team advanced to the NAIA National Tournament where they finished in ninth place. In the course of the season the team compiled a 53-9 record.

text.headline: IUPUI softball team won NAIA District 21 Tournament
text.text: For the ninth year in a row, the IUPUI softball team won the NAIA District 21 Tournament.
text.secondary_text: In National Tournament play, the Metros team placed ninth. For the season, the team compiled a 50-9 record: 20-0 against District 21 rivals and 22-6 against National Collegiate Athletics Association (NCAA) competition. After this season, coach P. Nicholas Kellum resigned. He compiled a 518-134 record coaching the IUPUI team.

text.headline: First annual Noche Latina held at IUPUI
IUPUI hosted the National Sports Festival
text.text: On July 23, 1982, the National Sports Festival commenced on the IUPUI campus.
text.secondary_text: Sponsored by the United States Olympic Committee, the Festival featured track and field, swimming, and other sporting events. The recently completed Indiana University Natatorium and Track Stadium were the sites of many of the competitions. Over 2,600 athletes competed. The event brought significant national attention to IUPUI and Indianapolis, which billed itself as the "amateur sports capital" of the country. IUPUI's sports venues were an integral part of the city's sports ambitions. The Festival continued through July 31.

media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Creation of IUPUI Diversity Cabinet
text.text: In response to the desire to improve racial, ethnic, and cultural diversity at IUPUI, Chancellor Gerald L. Bepko created the Diversity Cabinet.
text.secondary_text: Its charge was to "increase diversity and improve the climate for diversity . . ., to renew and redouble our efforts to enhance diversity . . ., [and] focus on the entire range of our diversity initiatives in new ways." The cabinet resided organizationally within the office of the chancellor and was staffed by Bepko's special assistant Paula Parker-Sawyers. It first met on November 4, 1999, and included campus and community leaders, including Sam H. Jones of the Indianapolis Urban League.
text.tertiary_text: Bepko acknowledged that IUPUI was "not doing as well as it could" in advancing diversity and voiced his wish to improve diversity on campus. The Cabinet advanced several initiatives, including issuing an annual report, State of Diversity at IUPUI, which first appeared in January 2000.

media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: The IU Board of Trustees approved the IUPUI Campus Master Plan
text.text: In February 2011, the Indiana University Board of Trustees approved an IUPUI Campus Master Plan, on which work had started in 2008.
text.secondary_text: The Plan included strategic thought involving the IU Health hospitals contiguous to the IUPUI campus as well as thinking about ways to expand onto the Wishard Memorial Hospital footprint immediately to the north of campus. In 2009 campus and IU Health leaders began to plan together. An important element in the planning was the referendum in November 2009 in which voters decided to construct a new county hospital to replace Wishard.
text.tertiary_text: Eventually, IU and the Marion County Health and Hospitals Corporation agreed to a land swap by which the university gained the Wishard buldings and land, and the county received the area on the west end of campus occupied by the Union Building and parking lots. On this space Eskenazi Health Hospital rose. The university razed some of the buildings on the former Wishard campus and occupied those that were useful.

text.headline: IUPUI Faculty Council approved PLUS
text.text: On May 1, 2018, the IUPUI Faculty Council formally endorsed Profiles of Learning for Undergraduate Success, or IUPUI+ (PLUS).
text.secondary_text: PLUS replaced the Principles of Undergraduate Learning (PULs) and the Principles of Co-curricular Learning (PCLs), which governed desired outcomes for IUPUI undergraduate students' experiences both inside and outside the classroom.

text.headline: Chancellor Maynard K. Hine appointed Nick Kellum director of intramural activities and coordinator of sports clubs
Creation of Genesis literary magazine
text.text: The student literary magazine, Genesis, began publication.

text.headline: IUPUI Joined NAIA and AIAW
text.text: Men's basketball, tennis, and golf joined National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA).
text.secondary_text: Women's basketball, softball, and volleyball joined Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women (AIAW). AIAW later merged into NAIA and NCAA.

media.caption: Sigma Theta Tau building dedication.
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Headquarters for Sigma Theta Tau International Honor Society for Nursing opened on the IUPUI campus.
text.text: Six nurses from the IU School of Nursing established the organization in 1922.
text.secondary_text: They named the organization after Greek words for love, courage, and honor. The aim was to build an organization to foster nursing education and scholarship, the first for the nursing profession. Beginning in 1936, Sigma Theta Tau was the first US organization to fund nursing research. In addition, it advances education, leadership, and career development. Throughout the decades, Sigma Theta Tau maintained its close relations with the IU School of Nursing.
text.tertiary_text: Incorporated as STTI in 1985, the organization supports scholarship and excellence in nursing practice. It organizes international scholarly conferences, disperses scholarships, and encourages excellence in nursling. The organization has more than 135,000 active members from more than 90 countries. With Sigma Theta Tau on its campus, IUPUI is at the center of nursing leadership worldwide.

media.caption: Dr. Craig Brater, Dean of the IU School of Medicine, at his desk

text.headline: The Indiana University School of Medicine launched the Indiana Genomics Initiative with a $105 million grant from Lilly Endowment, Inc.
text.text: This grant, the largest that Indiana University had ever received up to this point in its history and the largest that Lilly Endowment had ever awarded, built on existing resources at the IU School of Medicine.
text.secondary_text: The Indiana Genomics Initiative enabled Central Indiana to emerge as a major center for research in life sciences. Lilly Endowment gave another $50 million to the project in spring 2003. IU hired a highly advanced pool of physicians and researchers and also invested in a super computer to support their search for new discoveries. The initiative allowed the integration of genetic research throughout the IU School of Medicine.
text.tertiary_text: Primary areas of research included genomics, bioinformatics, medical informatics, bioethics, and education. By 2010, Lilly Endowment’s $155 million in grants for the Indiana Genomics Initiative had resulted in an additional $682 million in research grant awards, more than 60 international patents, and a number of new life sciences companies. The Indiana Genomics Initiative also established Central Indiana as a center for biotechnology and translational research, turning observations in the laboratory and clinic into real health improvements.

text.headline: IUPUI leaders dedicated the new School of Engineering and Technology Building.
text.text: The dedication event was the culmination of years of planning and work to move former Purdue programs from the 38th Street campus to downtown.
text.secondary_text: Consolidation of all IUPUI schools on the near-west-side campus had been a key element of the influential Goals and Objectives Committee, which reported to Chancellor Maynard Hine in 1973. Hine's successor, Irwin, followed through by fundraising and mobilizing support for the new construction. Once in its new downtown home, the School of Engineering and Technology went on to build strong undergraduate and graduate programs.

text.headline: The IU Student Outreach Clinic, a partnership of several IUPUI schools, won the Governor's Service Award for exemplary service learning.
text.text: The clinic is a student-run and staffed initiative to provide free medical, dental, and other services to uninsured, underserved, and under-resourced members of the Indianapolis community.
text.secondary_text: Student-led and operated clinics to serve the city's populace have a long history at IUPUI. The IU School of Nursing ran the South Side Community Health Center, at 234 West Morris Street. There citizens obtained free services from School of Medicine and School of Nursing students. In return, students gained experience serving people's needs. The IU Student Outreach Clinic, its successor, operates instead on the city’s east side and is coordinated by the IU School of Medicine. The clinic provides services on a first-come, first-served basis.
text.tertiary_text: Participating in the clinic with the School of Medicine are the IU School of Dentistry, the IU School of Social Work, the IU School of Nursing, the IU School of Health and Human Sciences, and the IU Robert H. McKinney School of Law, all parts of IUPUI. The Krannert School of Physical Therapy of the University of Indianapolis also participates.

text.headline: Indiana and Purdue University Presidents Agreed to Merge Indianapolis Campuses
text.text: After Mayor Richard Lugar called for establishment of an independent state university for Indianapolis, the presidents of Purdue and IU met in secret in late December and agreed to a merger.
text.secondary_text: The Boards of Trustees of the two universities quickly ratified the merger. IUPUI was born on January 24, 1969.

media.caption: Dr. John C. Buhner, 1977 UA24-002443
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Jack M. Ryder appointed vice chancellor; John C. Buhner appointed vice chancellor
text.text: IU president Joseph L. Sutton and Purdue University president Frederick L. Hovde jointly appointed Jack M. Ryder as vice chancellor at IUPUI, to oversee the merger of the two universities in Indianapolis.
text.secondary_text: Since 1963 the dean of the PU-Indianapolis Extension, Ryder, who received the PhD from Michigan State University in higher education administration, would also continue to manage the Purdue academic programs. In 7 the Indiana University Board of Trustees appointed John C. Buhner vice chancellor at IUPUI, effective 10 1. Holding a PhD in political science from IU-Bloomington, “Jack” Buhner arrived from Indiana University Northwest in Gary, where he had worked since 1948 and had risen to dean and acting chancellor.
text.tertiary_text: At IUPUI Buhner had responsibility for academic affairs, recruiting new faculty, retaining those already here, and supervising the promotion and tenure processes. He assumed oversight of the merger of the academic programs of IU and Purdue in Indianapolis. He also ushered in new graduate and undergraduate programs. Dr. Ryder became responsible for merging all administrative operations. In 1970 Buhner added dean of the faculties to his job title. In 1977 Buhner became associate dean of the faculties and professor of political science in the School of Liberal Arts.

media.caption: IUPUC sign, 1978 1078-0570-001
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Columbus Center of IUPUI opened Community leaders in the Indiana
text.text: Community leaders in the Indiana city of Columbus had long desired to provide higher-education opportunities to residents.
text.secondary_text: The city was the home of major industries; these companies wanted local venues for training their employees in management, technological, and scientific techniques. Corporate and municipal leaders together advanced the idea of a "Columbus Community College," taking it to the Indiana General Assembly. However, the legislature rejected the idea. Next, leaders approached existing public universities in the state. Indiana University and Purdue University responded in 1969 by assigning the development of a Columbus campus to the newly created IUPUI.
text.tertiary_text: In August 1970, IUPUI announced the birth of "Columbus Center of IUPUI." It officially opened on August 17, 1970 with two employees, a director and a secretary. At the start, all classes were held in rented public-school classrooms around town. Offices were located in a former armory in the downtown (which also housed Indiana Vocational and Technical College). Later, city leaders secured the local Air Force base facilities as the campus home, where it continues to reside.

text.headline: IU Assumed administrative control of IUPUI
text.text: After a two-year period during which leaders sorted and reorganized the administrative and academic functions of the Indianapolis campuses of Indiana University and Purdue University, IU assumed overall responsibility for management of IUPUI.
text.secondary_text: IUPUI chancellor Maynard K. Hine placed all administrative functions under business manager Arthur D. Lautzenheiser.

media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Second Chancellor of IUPUI appointed
text.text: Dr. Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., was selected as the second chancellor of IUPUI. Irwin worked at the Indiana University School of Medicine and served as the Dean.

text.headline: Edward C. Moore Appointed Executive Vice Chancellor
text.text: IU board of trustees approved President John W. Ryan’s appointment of Edward C. Moore as executive vice chancellor at IUPUI.
text.secondary_text: Moore’s appointment came at the same time Glenn W. Irwin, Jr., became chancellor. Moore, a philosopher with a PhD from the University of Michigan, took over the task of building the faculty and academic programs on the campus. In 1977, Moore’s title changed to dean of the faculties, taking over from Jack Buhner. Moore was also named executive dean. Shortly after Moore arrived in Indianapolis, IU reorganized, designating Bloomington and Indianapolis as “core campuses” in the system, creating core schools (e.g., Business and SPEA) split between them.
text.tertiary_text: Within this new framework Moore worked to improve the quality of the faculty and bolster academic programs on the campus. Among other accomplishments, Moore brought the Charles Sanders Peirce documentary editing project to IUPUI. He recalled that he enjoyed meshing the IU Medical Center programs with other IU and Purdue schools on campus. When he stepped down in 1982, IUPUI boasted 144 degree programs.

text.headline: IUPUI made a Core Campus of Indiana University
text.text: IUPUI received an updated status as a core campus within the Indiana University school system.

media.caption: Dr. Howard G. Schaller UA24-008363
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Howard G. Schaller appointed executive dean and dean of the faculties
text.text: Howard G. Schaller, executive associate dean of the IU School of Business, replaced Edward C. Moore as executive dean and dean of the faculties.
text.secondary_text: Schaller (PhD Duke University), a member of the IU faculty in business economics since 1964, recalled shortly after taking the job in Indianapolis that IUPUI was a unique institution.” It was the “most complete campus in the state,” he said. "Bloomington does not have a school of engineering and West Lafayette does not have law."
text.tertiary_text: IUPUI grew rapidly during the 1980s, and Schaller helped develop programs for women and returning adults. He was integrally involved in the formation of the IU Center on Philanthropy. After he stepped down as executive dean he served as the founding director of the Center in 1987–1988. Schaller resigned from the dean of the faculties position in 1987 and retired as executive dean in 1988.

media.caption: Dr. Gerald L. Bepko (right) filling balloon at IUPUI Fall Festival, 1989 989-3716-022
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Third Chancellor of IUPUI Appointed
text.text: Gerald L. Bepko, JD was named the third chancellor of IUPUI after serving as dean of the Indiana University School of Law-Indianapolis (now the IU Robert H. McKinney School of Law).
text.secondary_text: As chancellor, Bepko worked to strengthen IUPUI’s position within Indiana’s higher education system and to make it a model urban university. He stressed the "research corridor" of IU-Bloomington, Purdue-West Lafayette, and IUPUI, where research in such fields as technology and the life sciences would aid in the economic development of Indiana and help slow the migration of the state’s college graduates to other parts of the country.
text.tertiary_text: During Bepko’s years as chancellor, many new undergraduate and graduate programs were added, and University College was created. It provided orientation, mentoring and tutoring programs, and learning communities to help first-year students stay in school.

media.caption: Dr. William M. Plater, 1990 690-4023-009
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: William M. Plater appointed dean of the faculties
text.text: William M. Plater, previously dean of the IUPUI School of Liberal Arts, received the appointment of dean of the faculties.
text.secondary_text: In 1988 he also took the title of executive vice chancellor for IUPUI. Plater worked hand in hand with IUPUI chancellor Gerald L. Bepko, appointed in 1986, to maintain the rapid development of the campus’s academic programs. Shortly after assuming his new positions, Plater drafted the IUPUI Development Plan: 1988–2000, which shaped the university’s growth in the coming decades. Many new graduate and undergraduate programs arose during his tenure. University College emerged during his tenure, an effort to support incoming students and retain them better.
text.tertiary_text: Plater was instrumental in making service learning a key element in the student experience at IUPUI; the Center on Service and Learning (among many other centers, institutes, and academic units) arose under his leadership. Plater became acting chancellor of IUPUI in early 2003 when Bepko served as interim president of IU. Plater retired his executive vice chancellor/dean of the faculties appointment in 2006. He continued to be active on campus in SPEA and the Center on Philanthropy (later the Lilly Family School of Philanthropy) building relationships with universities around the globe.

text.headline: Fourth Chancellor of IUPUI Appointed
text.text: Dr. Charles R. Bantz became the fourth chancellor of IUPUI.
text.secondary_text: He had previously served as the provost and senior vice president for academic affairs at Wayne State University in Detroit, and was the first chancellor who with no previous connections to IUPUI. During his tenure as chancellor (2003-2015), Bantz advanced an ambitious agenda of growth in research, research funding, and academic programs. Many new undergraduate and graduate degree programs arose.
text.tertiary_text: Bantz approved the Multicultural Success Center in response to student calls. As well, Herron School of Art and Design relocated to the downtown campus, completing a forty-year process of consolidating all IUPUI schools to the near-westside.

text.headline: Nasser H. Paydar appointed executive vice chancellor and chief academic officer
text.text: In 2012, Nasser H. Paydar became executive vice chancellor and chief academic officer of IUPUI, a change in the position’s name but not its duties.
text.secondary_text: Paydar had long roots at IUPUI, having since 1985 been a member of the mechanical engineering faculty in the School of Engineering and Technology. He went on to administrative appointments in the school, and later became vice chancellor and dean of IUPUC, and then chancellor at IU-East in Richmond. During his tenure, working closely with Chancellor Charles R. Bantz, he developed the strategic plan for IUPUI, Our Commitment to Indiana and Beyond. In November 2015 he succeeded Bantz to become IUPUI’s chancellor.

text.headline: Kathy Johnson appointed executive vice chancellor and chief academic officer
text.text: Kathy E. Johnson began as interim executive vice chancellor of IUPUI in August 2015 and received the permanent appointment in July 2016.
text.secondary_text: Johnson, who received the PhD in psychology from Emory University, joined the Department of Psychology in the Purdue School of Science in 1993. Her areas of research include cognition and development. She has published extensively. She served as chair of the department from 2008 to 2011, and then became dean and associate vice chancellor for undergraduate education in IUPUI's University College. She spearheaded the creation of IUPUI's Division of Undergraduate Education in 2014.

text.headline: Goals and Objectives Committee Formed
text.text: Chancellor Maynard K. Hine formed the Goals and Objectives Committee (GO Committee) to develop a long-range plans for IUPUI.
text.secondary_text: Chaired by IU School of Law-Indianapolis professor James P. White, the GO Committee met frequently over several years and formulated influential plans for the growth and development of the IUPUI campus, including influential reports in 1971 and 1973.

text.headline: IUPUI and Ivy Tech signed agreement to coordinate admissions and registration
text.text: IUPUI chancellor Gerald L. Bepko and Indiana Vocational and Technical College chancellor Meredith L. Carter signed an agreement to work together to assist students progress through their post-secondary education.
text.secondary_text: The institutions would cooperate to streamline student counseling in matters relative to admissions, course selection, cross-registration, and more. The schools would use new computer technologies in these efforts. IUPUI and Ivy Tech had long cooperated through the Consortium on Urban Education (CUE). The new agreement advanced their collaboration, with plans to investigate additional paths to cooperate to serve students’ educational needs.

text.headline: IUPUI Development Plan, 1988–2000
text.text: The IUPUI Development Plan: 1988–2000 was a significant document that laid out the direction that IUPUI chancellor Gerald L. Bepko and executive vice chancellor/dean of the faculties William M. Plater wished to take.
text.secondary_text: They envisioned strengthening and improving existing academic programs and broadening the range of programs available to students. Improving library resources for faculty and students was a keynote of the plan. Previously, nonmedical library holdings had been woefully deficient. Under the plan, a vision for developing a technologically advanced University Library to serve faculty and students took form.

media.caption: Men's basketball team 1982–1983 1182-1522-063
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: IUPUI men’s basketball team won their first post-season tournament game
text.text: The IUPUI Metros squad defeated Huntington College 89–82 in the first round of the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) District 21 playoffs.
text.secondary_text: Huntington had taken an early lead, but the Metros came back quickly to seize the lead and never relinquished it. Freshman Kayle Funkhouser led the team with 29 points. The team advanced to the second round but lost to top-seeded Grace College by two points.

text.headline: The Office of Minority Affairs opened
text.text: The Office of Minority Affairs opened during the fall semester, directed by former IU Basketball player Landon M. Turner.
text.secondary_text: The office was located in Cavanaugh Hall, and "aimed at linking the administration with minorities and is also targeted at attempting to retain minority college recruits, whose numbers have shown a decline in recent years." Other goals included informing minority students about scholarships and job opportunities.

text.headline: Women's basketball team won District 21 championship
Women's basketball team won District 21 championship
text.text: The Metros advanced to the NAIA National Tournament.

text.headline: Women's tennis team won Great Lakes Sub-Region II tournament
text.text: The Metros advanced to the NAIA National Tournament.

text.headline: Women's tennis team won Great Lakes Sub-Region II tournament
text.text: The Metros advanced to the NAIA National Tournament.

text.headline: Indiana University School of Medicine received $5 million to establish the IU Alcohol Research Center
text.text: Indiana University has been heavily involved in alcohol research since the 1930s when Dr. Rolla Harger invented the ‘Drunk-O-Meter’ at IU, the predecessor to the breathalyzer, also developed at IU.
text.secondary_text: In fact, in 1987, researchers at IU already held ten grants supported by the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism (NIAAA), a branch of the NIH. Built on its long legacy of alcohol research and a strong grant proposal from Dr. Ting-Kai Li, Indiana University School of Medicine received $5 million from the NIAAA in 1987 to establish the IU Alcohol Research Center (IARC), a first of its kind in the United States. From experimental models developed in the 1970s, Dr. Li had observed that certain groups of rats voluntarily drank large amounts of alcohol even when food and water were freely available. These alcohol-preferring animal lines have since been used in over thirty research centers in four countries.
text.tertiary_text: It was the original mission of the IU Alcohol Research Center to investigate the genetic and psychosocial aspects of alcoholism as well as the biological and molecular basis for differences in the way individuals react to alcohol. With an interdisciplinary team of biochemists, neuroscientists, and psychiatrists along with a rat model that provided a means of studying the neurobiological basis of alcohol-seeking behavior, the IARC was the first center to research and provide evidence that alcoholism is a disease that is dependent on both genetic and environmental risk factors. The IARC continued to develop methods of DNA analyzation that verified specific genes as being associated with alcoholism, alcoholic liver disease, pancreatitis, dementia, and depression. The IARC has received continuous funding over the past thirty years from the NIAAA with a continued focus on biological bases for differences in the way people drink alcohol as well as the trajectories that lead to alcohol-use disorders.

text.headline: The Campus Hotel and Conference Center opened
text.text: Completed at a cost of $12 million, University Place Conference Center and Hotel provided quality service to visitors and guests to IUPUI and Indianapolis until it was converted to student housing and teaching space in 2013.
text.secondary_text: Lilly Endowment, Inc. and the Krannert Charitable Trust contributed half of the money needed to complete the $12-million facility. The conference center and hotel became an important asset for IUPUI and the community. It was a focal point of campus that enhanced the reputation of IUPUI by giving the campus the opportunity to host a variety of meetings and conferences. It played an important role in fostering a thriving convention and tourism business in the city. During the early years of its existence, the conference center held important meetings such as the Presidential Aids Commission Hearings in 1988 and the Indiana Earth Day Conference in 1990.
text.tertiary_text: The conference center also provided lodging for the US Swimming and Diving Olympic trials in 1992. In 2012, the New England Patriots stayed in the hotel while they were in town for Super Bowl XLVI. By 2012, the complexion of the campus’s student population was changing. The need for housing on campus had reached a crisis point, with more than 200 students wait-listed. Converting University Place Conference Center and Hotel to accommodate these students fit with the campus master plan. Several studies revealed that students who live on university campuses have better retention rates and better grade point averages. Renamed Hine Hall and University Tower, the former conference center and hotel offers residential space for 560 students, IUPUI’s first student dining hall with a seating capacity of 470, and 30,000 square feet of classroom space.

text.headline: Men's Soccer team established

text.headline: IUPUI Hosted Pan American Games
text.text: On August 9, 1987, the Pan-American Games commenced on the IUPUI campus. A major international sports competition featuring national teams from South, Central, and North America, the Games began in 1937.
text.secondary_text: Following a hiatus caused by World War Two, the competition resumed in 1951 and grew in size and scope. The 1987 Games in Indianapolis were the culmination of years of planning by municipal leaders who were intent on showcasing Indianapolis as a major sports city. IUPUI contributed its sports venues and campus administrators took leading roles in preparations. The Games continued through August 23.

text.headline: IUPUI Hosted US Olympic Track and Field Trials
text.text: From July 15 through July 23, the Track Stadium hosted trial competitions to select members of the United States Olympic Team to compete later that summer.
text.secondary_text: Among many notable athletic performances that occurred during the trials, Florence Griffith Joyner set the world record for the 100-meter race with a 10.49 seconds time.

text.headline: The Minority Achievement Scholarship program established
text.text: Program was later renamed the Norman Brown Diversity and Leadership Scholars Program to honor the associate director of the IUPUI Office of Undergraduate Admissions who had helped develop it.

text.headline: Creation of the Alzheimer's Disease Center in the IU School of Medicine
text.text: The National Institute on Aging gave a five-year, $2.5 million grant to establish the center.
text.secondary_text: The center has been very successful in research and diagnosis of this terrible disease. Dr. Hugh Hendrie took the lead in the development of the Alzheimer’s research program at the Indiana University School of Medicine starting in 1987. He and other physicians and researchers established the center in 1991 to bring comprehensive support to patients who were suffering from Alzheimer’s disease and to their families as well. Early services of the Alzheimer’s Disease Center included home visits, family counseling, and complete diagnostics. During its first year in 1991, researchers began a groundbreaking study in Ibadan, Nigeria, hoping to learn how risk factors differ between Africans in Nigeria and African Americans in Indianapolis. The study concluded in 2001, and investigators found that African Americans are twice as likely to develop Alzheimer’s Disease and other dementia related illnesses than Africans in Ibadan. This study was the first to compare incident rates for the disease in industrialized and nonindustrialized populations.
text.tertiary_text: The Alzheimer’s Disease Center was also responsible for finding mutations in the Amyloid Precursor Protein gene that is responsible for a form of hereditary Alzheimer’s Disease as well as Gerstmann Sträussler Scheinker disease, an early-onset, extremely rare, and usually familial neurodegenerative disease. In 2017, the National Institute on Aging awarded a $7.6-million grant to the IU School of Medicine to establish a network of sites across the United States to study early-onset Alzheimer’s Disease. Liana G. Apostolova, MD, the Barabara and Peer Baekgaard Professor of Alzheimer’s Disease Research, leads this study that enrolled a large cohort of early-onset Alzheimer’s disease participants to better understand this rare variant of Alzheimer’s Disease.

text.headline: Women’s Volleyball took second place in NAIA tourney
text.text: After advancing to the NAIA final four, the IUPUI women's volleyball team came in second place in the tournament.

media.url: The goal of the center was to help boost Indianapolis’s image as an international city, as well as establishing IUPUI as one of the top schools in the nation for research and teaching in urban and environmental policy. The institution also aimed to help local communities, governments, and corporations deal with any problems relating to urban or environmental policy. To help accomplish those goals the research center and school focused on four specific areas, state and local government fiscal policy, environmental policy, neighborhood development, and public health and indigent health care. A lot of planning went into the center before it opened. Organizers consulted nineteen private organizations and eighteen schools to help perfect the Center for Urban Policy and the Environment’s mission. Lilly Endowment, Inc., gave IUPUI $8.5 million to launch the center. During the center’s first four years of existence it initiated over 127 projects and raised over $3.9 million in funds from contracts. The Center for Urban Policy and the Environment was later renamed the Public Policy Institute but still offered the same great research and education that it offered before. As of 2019, the Public Policy Institute expanded its focus of research into six different research areas, criminal justice, economic development, housing and community development, land use and environment, public safety, and tax and finance.
media.caption: Tom Guevara, Director, IU Public Policy Institute.

text.headline: The Public Policy Institute opened as the Center for Urban Policy and the Environment in the IUPUI School of Public and Environmental Affairs (SPEA)
text.text: The goal of the center was to help boost Indianapolis’s image as an international city, as well as establishing IUPUI as one of the top schools in the nation for research and teaching in urban and environmental policy.
text.secondary_text: The institution also aimed to help local communities, governments, and corporations deal with any problems relating to urban or environmental policy. To help accomplish those goals the research center and school focused on four specific areas, state and local government fiscal policy, environmental policy, neighborhood development, and public health and indigent health care. A lot of planning went into the center before it opened. Organizers consulted nineteen private organizations and eighteen schools to help perfect the Center for Urban Policy and the Environment’s mission. Lilly Endowment, Inc., gave IUPUI $8.5 million to launch the center.
text.tertiary_text: During the center’s first four years of existence it initiated over 127 projects and raised over $3.9 million in funds from contracts. The Center for Urban Policy and the Environment was later renamed the Public Policy Institute but still offered the same great research and education that it offered before. As of 2019, the Public Policy Institute expanded its focus of research into six different research areas, criminal justice, economic development, housing and community development, land use and environment, public safety, and tax and finance.

text.headline: NCAA Division II status approved
Men's golf reintroduced
The IU School of Medicine established the Ryan White Center for Pediatric Infectious Disease and Global Health
text.text: Ryan White, the first child to speak out about HIV infection, was a patient of Marty Kleiman, MD, founder of the Division of Pediatric Infectious Disease at the IU School of Medicine.
text.secondary_text: Ryan contracted HIV through a blood transfusion when he was in middle school. He gave a face to this misunderstood and feared disease. Dr. Kleiman worked with Jeanne White, Ryan’s mother, to provide the best of care for him at Riley Hospital for Children in the years before an effective treatment for HIV was discovered. Ryan died in 1990, but his willingness to bring awareness of HIV to the public led to enhanced education and substantial progress in HIV research and care.
text.tertiary_text: In 1991, Jill Stewart Waibel, MD, a close friend of Ryan’s, founded the Indiana University Dance Marathon to raise funds for HIV research and awareness to honor his memory. In 1996, the IU School of Medicine was able to establish the Ryan White Center for Pediatric Infectious Disease and Global Health to carry on his legacy. The center works to lessen stigma associated with HIV, cares for about 600 inpatients and well over 1,800 outpatients per year and prepares physicians, nurses, and other specialists in treatment. In addition to providing world-class clinical care and education, it is a world leader in research in HIV and other pediatric infectious diseases that affect children.

text.headline: Clarian Health integrated operations of Riley and Indiana University hospitals along with Methodist Hospital, formerly one of the nation’s largest private hospitals.
text.secondary_text: Indiana University’s decision to turn over healthcare management services to Clarian Health allowed the IU School of Medicine to develop further as a first-rate medical education institution and assured the economic viability of Indiana University Hospitals for future generations. As the Indiana University School of Medicine rapidly expanded its education, research, and patient care programs with increased demand for healthcare and its booming innovations, IU began struggling to internally manage and operate University Hospital and Riley Hospital at the IU Medical Center. The largest private health care facility in the state, Methodist Hospital, which had operated independently since 1908, joined with Indiana University Hospitals to form Clarian Health. Indiana University entrusted Clarian Health with the management and operation of Indiana University Hospitals, including patient care programs and all other healthcare resources, so that the IU School of Medicine could turn its focus towards medical education and research.
text.tertiary_text: In an effort to unify the then physically disconnected entities of Indiana University Medical Center and Methodist Hospital into one consolidated medical campus, Clarian Health constructed the now well-known ‘people mover’ tram to operate between the two. This significant visionary and financial commitment created the feel of one campus for Methodist and IU Hospitals in a practical way by establishing a much faster and safer mode of transportation between the two locations than the previous shuttling system. The people mover, however, ceased operation in February 2019 due to high maintenance and operation costs, and a surface shuttle system was reinstated. As the relationship between Clarian Health and Indiana University grew and became more exclusive through the extended work of establishing sixteen IU Hospitals throughout the state of Indiana, Clarian Health took on the name of Indiana University Health in early 2011.

text.headline: IUPUI granted NCAA Division I status, joined Mid-Continent Conference
text.text: On October 30, 1997, the IU Board of Trustees voted to approve a proposal for IUPUI intercollegiate athletics to join NCAA Division I.
text.secondary_text: Founded in 1971, IUPUI intercollegiate athletics, then nicknamed the Metros, joined the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA) in 1978. In 1993, the school moved to NCAA Division II. However, IUPUI was the largest campus by enrollment in all of Division II by 1997. IUPUI, therefore, saw an opportunity to increase its national profile by developing its athletics programs to keep up with the campus’s growing population and academic achievement. Developing institutional pride among the student body and distinguishing itself as distinct from its parent campuses in West Lafayette and Bloomington had proven to be a challenge for IUPUI.
text.tertiary_text: Chancellor Gerald Bepko and Athletic Director Michael Moore saw the move to Division I as a way to increase school spirit among students and to develop a unique identity for IUPUI. Along with boosting school pride, the move also increased the number of scholarships available and exposed IUPUI to a national audience. To meet the Division I requirement of 14 sports and adequate gender equity, IUPUI added Men’s Swimming and Diving, Women’s Golf, Women’s Soccer, and Women’s Track and Field teams. In November 1997, IUPUI accepted an invitation to join the Mid-Continent Conference, which had actively recruited IUPUI and assisted in its move up to Division I. To reinforce the sense of beginning a new era of IUPUI athletics, students were given a chance to vote on a new mascot and logo. Starting with the Fall 1998 semester, the IUPUI Metros became the IUPUI Jaguars.

text.headline: Men's and women's cross country started
Jaguar established as IUPUI Mascot
Men's soccer team won regular season championship
Men's soccer team won conference tournament
Men's baseball discontinued
Inaugural Jagathon Dance Marathon
text.text: The IUPUI Student Foundation hosted the inaugural Jagathon, part of the Indiana University Dance Marathon, to raise money for Riley Hospital for Children on the IUPUI campus.
text.secondary_text: Starting at 3 pm on Saturday, February 22, IUPUI students danced 18 hours through the afternoon, night, and into the morning of Sunday, February 24. The event took place in the Union Building, which has since been razed. Sidney and Lois Eskenazi Hospital now occupies the place where the Union Building stood. Thirty IUPUI students danced in the inaugural event and raised just over $2000. Jagathon has taken place each year since 2002. The event has grown in scope and impact. In 2018, Jagathon raised a record $501,371.24. Overall, Jagathon has raised more $1.25 million for pediatric research at Riley, becoming one of the biggest college dance marathon programs in the United States.

text.headline: Women's tennis won both regular season and conference tournament
Men's basketball won Mid-Continent conference tourney, qualified for NCAA Division I tourney
text.text: The Jaguars lost to University of Kentucky Wildcats March 21, 2003 95-64 in first round regional in Minneapolis.

media.caption: D. Wade Clapp, MD, with Emily Hampton, of California, a neurofibramatosis patient.

text.headline: D. Wade Clapp, MD and other researchers announced the first effective treatment for nerve tumors that develop in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)
text.text: Clapp, chairman of the Department of Pediatrics and a researcher at the IU Simon Cancer Center and Herman B Wells Center for Pediatric Research, made this breakthrough with colleagues from other leading medical centers.
text.secondary_text: They used an FDA-approved drug called Gleevec that shrunk tumors in children with NF1, the most common neurological disorder caused by a single gene mutation. This mutation causes a variety of symptoms. The most severe are tumors that grow along nerve tissue. They cause problems if they press against vital organs. Although NF1 is not as well-known as either muscular dystrophy or Huntington's Disease, it is more prevalent. It affects 1 in 3,000 children. Clapp has continued his NF1 research. In 2015, his project became part of the coveted National Cancer Institute (NCI) Specialized Programs of Research Excellence Initiatives (SPORE), the first of these to focus on pediatric cancers.

text.headline: Chen Ni won NCAA Division I platform diving championship
Chen Ni won NCAA Division I platform diving championship
The IUPUI Women's Volleyball Team made its first appearance in the NCAA Tournament
text.text: The Jaguars faced the #4 Missouri Tigers—the only remaining unbeaten volleyball team in the country.

text.headline: Indy Eleven played first season in Carroll Stadium
text.text: Established in 2013, the Indy Eleven, made its debut in Carroll Stadium as a member of the North American Soccer League.

text.headline: IUPUI Men's Cross-country team won first Summit League Championship
Indiana University School of Medicine began its partnership with Moi University in Eldoret, Kenya, which would become AMPATH
text.text: The IU School of Medicine (IUSM) initiated the partnership with Moi University when Doctors Bob Einterz, Joe Mamlin, Charlie Kelley, and Dave Van Reken set out on an international tour in 1988.
text.secondary_text: They were looking for a medical school that not only had the need but also the vision to create a medical school curriculum around a broad, community-based service. The Moi University School of Medicine Dean, Dr. Haroun N. K. arap Mengesh shared these goals, and Moi University welcome its first class of 40 medical students in 1990. Alongside Kenyan colleagues, IUSM doctors cared for Kenyan patients, conducted health research, and taught American and Kenyan medical students. The partnership between IUSM and Moi University was so successful that other North American universities joined.
text.tertiary_text: In 2001, the partnership became known as the Academic Model Providing Access to Health Care (AMPATH). With the support of the US Agency for International Development, the National Institutes of Health, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, AMPATH has attracted $112 million dollars, while producing 550 peer-reviewed journal articles pertaining to research and programs that provide health benefits to Kenyans. AMPATH became one of Africa’s largest, most comprehensive, and effective HIV/AIDS management and control systems. It has improved the lives of 4 million Kenyans not only through HIV testing and treatment but also maternal and child health, nutrition, counseling, and helping patients regain financial stability and independence. In 2007, Dr. Joe Mamlin, one of the founders of the program, was nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize, and US ambassador to Kenya, Michael Ranneberger, called AMPATH "an academic miracle."

text.headline: IUPUI Campus Center opened
text.text: As the IUPUI campus grew and all academic programs moved to West Michigan Street, it lacked an attractive central facility to serve all IUPUI students.
text.secondary_text: By the late 1980s, the aging Union Building that had been constructed in 1953 no longer was adequate. Cavanaugh Hall and what is now the University Tower were popular congregation locations, but there needed to be a more streamlined place for students to gather for down time. Chancellor Gerald L. Bepko declared construction of a campus center to be one of the most critical projects in IUPUI’s development to establish it as a modern university. In 1999, he hired Karen Whitney as vice chancellor for student life, to develop the financial planning and funding, design, and construction of a new campus center. After approving a design, finding an architect, and raising almost $50 million in funds from student fees, private sector financing, and gifts, Whitney began the most significant undertaking in IUPUI’s history.
text.tertiary_text: The Campus Center project involved hundreds of students, hundreds of alumni, a host of individuals from the university architect's office, the entire Office of Student Affairs, and all of the university leadership. All of IUPUI was heavily engaged in the Campus Center and the future of the university. A main concern for the center was its inclusion of food options, as many students hiked it to the nearby hospitals for food or scrounged from vending machines. Another issue was the addition of numerous classrooms, business rooms, auditoriums, and a theater for organizational use, and all were eventually included. In January of 2008, the Campus Center officially opened its doors to students, although it did not become fully accessible until April. The Campus Center serves as the home of the IUPUI student as a central location that links student life to academic life. The center is constantly changing to accommodate student needs, as seen with the constant additions for physical fitness, entertainment, and food options. The campus canter has and will continue to be the center for all campus activities, and it continues to validate IUPUI as an official campus in the eyes of all who visit.

text.headline: The Ronald McDonald House opened to provide a home away from home for the families of children receiving care at Riley Hospital for Children.
text.secondary_text: Riley was just one of many children’s hospitals across the country for which a Ronald McDonald House was constructed. The first opened in 1974. Philadelphia Eagles football player Fred Hill and his wife had the idea when their daughter was being treated for leukemia at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia. They realized that many families who traveled long distances to get specialized care for their children could not afford hospital rooms. Before Ronald McDonald Houses, parents often had to camp out on hospital chairs and benches and ate makeshift meals out of vending machines.
text.tertiary_text: Planning for the Ronald McDonald House on the IUPUI campus began in 1980. IU and “Our House,” a nonprofit organization composed of families, patients, doctors, and McDonald’s franchise owners, came together to operate the facility. Built on land donated by Indiana University, the original house had twenty-four rooms. In 1989, a new wing was constructed, adding twenty guest rooms and six apartments that were designed for transplant patients and their families. Two more rooms were added in 2001, and, in 2004, another six new guest rooms were included in one of Riley Hospital’s critical care units. A day respite area was also made available to any family with an inpatient. Since 1982, more than 35,000 families representing every Indiana county have stayed at the Ronald McDonald House. These families have not only found affordable housing at the house but also caring volunteers and staff to help them through difficult times.

text.headline: Dr. Richard Miyamoto became the first ear surgeon to put a cochlear implant in a child at Riley Hospital
text.text: Dr. Richard Miyamoto pioneered in cochlear implantation soon after he came to Riley Hospital in 1978.
text.secondary_text: He worked on trials of the device with his mentor Dr. William F. House, an American otologist, physician, and medical researcher who invented it. Miyamoto reported findings for the device in hearings to the FDA at Washington, DC, and fought for it, even when doctors in his field said that they would never work.
text.tertiary_text: In 1983, Trixie Taylor became the first child to get a cochlear implant. This surgery launched a pediatric research study at Riley that is still going on today. Miyamoto has always pushed to implant the device in the youngest of patients so that they are in an environment to hear language and speech and to get the education that they need.

text.headline: The Elks Cancer Center opened
text.text: The Elks Cancer Center was an important predecessor to the IU Simon Cancer Center.
text.secondary_text: The Elks Association has worked for over 50 years raising money for cancer ressearch at Indiana University. Lodges from all over the state have raised more than $4 million dollars for the cause. More recently, the Elks have directed money to support the research of young research scientists at the Simon Cancer Center. In 2008, they committed to funding a $1 million endowment to generate permanent funding for new generations of investigators to pursue careers in cancer research.

text.headline: The Charles S. Peirce Project moved to IUPUI
text.text: The Peirce project is a documentary editing project to publish the complete works of the influential American philosopher.
text.secondary_text: Peirce (1839–1914) is recognized worldwide as one of humanity's most rigorous, versatile, and seminal thinkers. The project moved to IUPUI from Texas Tech University and formed the core of what later would become the Institute of American Thought.

media.caption: Canoe racing at Eagle Creek, 1977
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: First Circle City Circuit canoe race held
text.text: The First Annual Circle City Circuit staged its First Annual Canoe Race at Eagle Creek Park on Indianapolis's west side.
text.secondary_text: Race heats began late in the morning, and involved a two-hundred-yard sprint with one turn. Event organizers promised "lots of spills, chills, and flying water amidst screams and shouts [for] help as the teams scramble to the finish line." Organizers also scheduled a "VIP race" of local TV celebrities. The race was just one part of a week-long "festival" dubbed the Circle City Circuit. Organizers explicitly aimed to create a tradition for everyone on the campus and focus attention on the young university. An international dinner at the Union Building commenced the Circuit, followed by a classical-music concert, a flea market, the Ice Cream Social, outdoor concerts, the annual Afro-American Conference, and more.
text.tertiary_text: As well, Herron celebrated its 75th anniversary. The event was the brainchild of IUPUI Student Association, the student government body, which hoped that the canoe race "would stress competition and perhaps become an annual affair. IU-Bloomington has its bicycle race and PU-West Lafayette has a go-kart contest but IUPUI has no similar traditional exercise in fun and purpose." According to the Sagamore, the IUPUI student newspaper, the canoe race was a "splashing success." Students Mark Finch and Lee Hooper won the race. The newspaper quoted one participant to say, "I didn't win, but boy, did I have a fun time. I can't wait until next year." The Circle City Circuit continued for several more years, but died out. In 2008 IUPUI commenced its Regatta, a canoe race on the canal in downtown Indianapolis. The Regatta has become a major event in the school year.

media.caption: Honors Convocation, 2007
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: First Chancellor's Honors Convocation held
text.text: In its first years, IUPUI had honored faculty and students for their distinguished academic achievements in separate ceremonies in schools or for faculty alone.
text.secondary_text: Chancellor Gerald L. Bepko desired to erase divisions by bringing students, staff, and faculty from IUPUI's many schools together in a campus-wide convocation. In prepared remarks for the event, he noted that "Today we begin a new tradition." He stressed a theme of unity and fostering relationships between disciplines. The convocation was a "symbol of campus unity . . . to celebrate the most important achievements of our IUPUI family."He added that it was fitting to do so twenty years after the merger of the Indianapolis campuses of Indiana University and Purdue University to create IUPUI. The event recognized the efforts of faculty, students, and academic counselors. Later, in 2001, Bepko created the Chancellor's Employee Recognition Convocation to include all staff, as well as faculty and students, whose work merited distinction.

media.caption: Herron homecoming, 1972
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: First Herron Alumni Homecoming held
text.text: IUPUI's Herron School of Art held its first Alumni Association Homecoming in 1972.
text.secondary_text: The event attracted artists who had studied at and graduated from Herron. It received a rolling start during the previous week with an exhibition titled, "Herron Highlights: History of the Art School," in the school's gallery, then located at 16th and Pennsylvania Streets. The exhibition featured works by former Herron instructors and students.
text.tertiary_text: It was divided into periods: "Antecedents, 1877–1890;" "The Forsyth Years, 1891–1933;" "The Mattison Years, 1933–1969," and "Indiana University, 1970-present." It included caricatures of faculty and students. The exhibition continued for another week after the Homecoming celebration. Herron has produced many distinguished artists in different genres. Starting in 1902 as an independent degree-granting art school under the auspices of the Art Association of Indianapolis with a bequest from Indianapolis businessman John Herron, the school merged with Indiana University in 1967.

media.caption: Chancellor Maynard K. Hine and IU President Joseph L. Sutton at dedication ceremony, 1970
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: University Hospital dedicated
text.text: University, city, and state leaders gathered to dedicate formally the recently completed University Hospital, built for $16.8 million and the first hospital in Indiana designed specifically as a teaching hospital for clinical medical education.
text.secondary_text: Thousands of students in the School of Medicine, School of Nursing, and the School of Dentistry began to train in the new facility, which replaced the aging Long and Coleman Hospitals on campus. Those buildings were converted to labs, classrooms, and office space. Hospital staff began to transfer patients from the older hospital buildings to University Hospital in January. While new, campus planners already had further construction in mind. Work on new annexes commenced within months of the dedication ceremony.

media.caption: School of Law building under construction, 1970
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: Roy Wilkins gave first Wendell L. Willkie Memorial Lecture in School of Law
text.text: Willkie (1892–1944) was a 1916 graduate of the IU School of Law in Bloomington.
text.secondary_text: A New York businessman and attorney, Willkie ran against President Franklin Roosevelt as the Republican Party nominee in 1940. He embraced social-justice reforms and the integration of the armed forces in his campaign. Despite a crushing electoral college defeat, Willkie continued his work in civil rights after the end of his campaign. In 1942, he addressed an NAACP convention, a pioneering act in its day.  The lecture at the IU School of Law-Indianapolis (now called the Robert H. McKinney School of Law) was established by Philip Willkie, Wendell Willkie’s only child. Citing a close friendship between his father and Wilkins, the younger Willkie saw the NAACP leader as an appropriate choice to give the first lecture. Wilkins (1901–1981) is remembered as a prominent Civil Rights leader.
text.tertiary_text: A New York journalist and national organizer, he was one of the planners of the 1963 March on Washington. He served as both executive secretary and executive director of the NAACP for many years. Under his leadership, the NAACP scored significant Civil Rights victories to advance equality under the law for all citizens, including the Brown v. Board of Education US Supreme Court ruling and the Voting Rights Act of 1965. Wilkins stepped down from his post in 1977 at the age of 76.

media.caption: University Library under construction, 1993
media.credit: IUPUI University Library Special Collections and Archives

text.headline: University Library opened
text.text: When Indiana University and Purdue University merged their operations in Indianapolis to form IUPUI in 1969, only the professional schools of Medicine, Law, and Dentistry had library resources sufficient to support faculty and student research.
text.secondary_text: In its first years IUPUI lacked adequate book and journal collections to support undergraduate and graduate programs and faculty development. In 1988, Chancellor Gerald L. Bepko and Executive Vice Chancellor/Dean of the Faculties William M. Plater highlighted this problem and made the construction of a large library facility and advanced electronic infrastructure for library resources keystones to the development of the campus.
text.tertiary_text: They secured generous funding from private donors and in the early 1990s embarked on building a new University Library. The construction was completed in the summer of 1993, when students, staff, and faculty joined together to carry books from existing libraries to the new building. Formal dedication of University Library occurred in 1994.

text.headline: National Art Museum of Sport opened in University Place Conference Center
text.text: Founded in 1959 by artist Germain G. Glidden, the not-for-profit organization first exhibited art works at Madison Square Garden in 1968.
text.secondary_text: It relocated to the University of New Haven in 1979. After exhibiting several works at the Pan American Games in Indianapolis in 1987, NAMOS received a grant from the Lilly Endowment, Inc., and moved to Indianapolis. NAMOS created a gallery in 1990 before the 1994 move to University Place.The National Art Museum of Sport's collections included more than 1000 works in bronze, photography, or on canvas created by prominent artists who portrayed athletes in action.
text.tertiary_text: Due to repurposing the University Place Conference Center and Hotel as classroom and student dormitory space in 2012, NAMOS left IUPUI and found space in the Children's Museum of Indianapolis.

text.headline: Indiana University president John Ryan reported plans for the Indiana University Center on Philanthropy would be implemented.
text.text: With a $4-million grant Lilly Endowment grant launched plans for the center, which had been initiated in 1986.
text.secondary_text: A planning committee investigated the feasibility of establishing the center to meet a growing need for understanding the role philanthropy in society and for better trained people to work in nonprofits. This planning committee produced a proposal that the the IU Board of Trustees approved in February 1987. Initial goals for the center included development of research in philanthropy and academic courses in cultural aspects of philanthropy. The original proposal also outlined programs in resource development and fundraising management and a professional field of public service in fundraising. In 1988, the Fund Raising School, which had been established in San Francisco in 1974, moved to the center, and the first philanthropy courses were held on the IUPUI campus.
text.tertiary_text: That same year Robert L. Payton, who had served as president of the Exxon Education Foundation, as United States ambassador to the Republic of Cameroon in West Africa, and as president of C. W. Post College and Hofstra University in New York, became founding director of the center. During these formative years, the IU Center on Philanthropy played a groundbreaking role in development of philanthropic studies as an academic discipline and field of study leading to the establishment of the IU School of Philanthropy in 2012, renamed the Lilly Family School of Philanthropy in 2013. The school is the first ever dedicated solely to the study and teaching of philanthropy.

text.headline: The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis was published.
text.text: The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis was the inaugural project of the Polis Center, which was established in the School of Liberal Arts in 1989.
text.secondary_text: During the 1970s and 1980s, Indianapolis had undergone considerable change, and IUPUI had developed and expanded alongside it. Up to that point, Indianapolis and its metropolitan area had been understudied. IUPUI faculty members recognized the opportunity to study Indianapolis as an example of a changing Mid-American city and created the Polis Center to carry out this mission. The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis was IUPUI's gift to the city upon the occasion of the campus's 20th anniversary.
text.tertiary_text: The Encyclopedia of Indianapolis included over 1,600 separate entries and featured the work of 485 community and academic experts. It became the standard comprehensive reference work on the city. Providing social, cultural, economic, historical, physical, and statistical information about Indianapolis and eight surrounding counties, it was considered a “model of what a modern city encyclopedia should be.” In 2018-2019, the Polis Center received funding from the Allen Whitehill Clowes Charitable Foundation to create the Digital Encyclopedia of Indianapolis for the city’s bicentennial in 2020-2021. The digital version will update and revise the Encyclopedia of Indianapolis in an innovative, digital, knowledge platform.

text.headline: Hine Chancellorship
text.text: Maynard K. Hine was the first chancellor of IUPUI and the first Hoosier elected president of the American Dental Association.

text.headline: Irwin Chancellorship
text.text: During Glenn Irwin Jr., M.D.'s chancellorship, IUPUI's visibility and respectability as an academic institution increased dramatically.

text.headline: Bepko Chancellorship
text.text: Gerald L. Bepko joined the faculty of the Indiana University School of Law at IUPUI in 1972, becoming a full professor in 1975.

text.headline: Bantz Chancellorship
text.text: Charles Bantz became the fourth chancellor of IUPUI in 2003, guiding the IUPUI campus through a period of growth and unprecedented student success.

text.headline: Paydar Chancellorship
text.text: Nasser H. Paydar, Ph.D., is named fifth chancellor of IUPUI in 2015
